Stem: Covered with dense whitish, felty hairs.
Leaves: Alternate, undivided, broadly to narrowy heart-shaped, with toothed margins, densely covered with whitish, felty hairs.
Flowers: Clustered, yellow to pale orange, with five petals. Stamens numerous, fused at the base.
FruitSeeds: Dry, dark brown, breaking apart into 8-10 one-seeded, wedge-shaped pieces with two curved barbs.
Habitat: Open woodlands, pastures, grasslands, crops, gardens.
DistinguishingFeatures: Differs from S. acuta and S. rhombifolia in the heart-shaped leaves with dense white hairs. There are also various native Australian Sida species.
